newsitem.title: THAILAND: Caltex to slow down Cambodia investment.
newsitem.headline: Caltex to slow down Cambodia investment.

text.p: American firm Caltex Petroleum Corp will slow investment in Cambodia pending its reassessment of the volatile political situation there, said regional vice-president Jock McKenzie on Wednesday.
The company has an investment of $20 million in Cambodia, including 12 service stations and an oil terminal in the western province of Sihanoukville.

"It's rather small compared to our overall portfolio. If anything, we will probably slow down the investment. It's a bit early to make judgement as it's not really that clear what would be the ultimate outcome of the political upheaval there," McKenzie said.
"I don't think we will sign an agreement to set up a new service station tomorrow," he said.
Weekend fighting in Cambodia resulted in Second Prime Minister Hun Sen ousting First Prime Minister Prince Norodom Ranariddh. There also was wholesale looting and violence in Phnom Penh.
McKenzie said one Caltex station was damaged and its first convenience store in Phnom Penh was looted just after its two-week debut.
He said that before the weekend fighting, Caltex had been considering investing more in Cambodia in a bid to capture 20 percent of the oil market share.
